tips.tip: Surgery is most effective for localized cavitary disease when antibiotics fail to close cavities after 6+ months, with 95% clearance at 1 year and 87% at 3 years post-surgery
tips.notes: Cleveland Clinic data cited in thread. Cavities with thick walls prevent antibiotic penetration - surgery removes the bacterial hub. Best outcomes when disease is localized to one area.

tips.tip: Ideal surgical candidates: localized disease, adequate lung function reserve, culture-negative for 12+ months on antibiotics, under age 70, and no significant comorbidities
tips.notes: Patients describe consulting with NJH surgeons and being evaluated on multiple factors. Surgery often combined with IV antibiotics before/after procedure.

tips.tip: Surgery combined with continued antibiotics for 12 months post-operation - surgery removes bacterial burden but antibiotics still needed to clear remaining bacteria in lungs
tips.notes: Standard protocol includes IV amikacin 2-3 months pre-surgery and continuing oral antibiotics 12 months post-surgery until culture conversion maintained.

tips.tip: Recovery timeline: hospital 3-5 days, return to light activities 2-3 weeks, return to work 2-8 weeks, full recovery 6-12 months depending on procedure extent
tips.notes: Minimally invasive/robotic surgery has faster recovery (2-3 weeks back to work) vs traditional thoracotomy (2-3 months). Walking immediately post-op speeds recovery.

tips.tip: Common post-surgical complications: nerve pain (resolves in 6 weeks), numbness at incision site (may be permanent), fatigue/low energy for 6-12 months, shortness of breath if extensive resection
tips.notes: Nerve pain common but temporary. Energy recovery takes longer than physical recovery - stamina building through exercise essential.

tips.tip: Dr. John Mitchell at NJH/University of Colorado and Dr. James Caccitolo in Tyler, TX are most frequently recommended thoracic surgeons for NTM patients
tips.notes: Dr. McShane (Tyler) only approves Mitchell or Caccitolo for her patients. Dr. Caccitolo uses computer-assisted minimally invasive surgery with excellent outcomes.

tips.tip: Minimally invasive/robotic surgery (VATS) offers faster recovery than traditional thoracotomy - patients walking hospital laps same day, driving within 1-2 weeks
tips.notes: Computer-assisted minimally invasive technique results in dramatically faster recovery - one patient back to work in 23 days, another drove 600 miles within 2 weeks.

tips.tip: Surgery does not guarantee cure - MAC can recur even after successful surgery, but recurrence risk is lower than continued antibiotic-only treatment with persistent cavities
tips.notes: Multiple patients report 5-20 years disease-free after surgery. Cavities are bacterial reservoirs - removing them plus continued airway clearance reduces reinfection risk significantly.

tips.tip: Wedge resection (small portion) vs segmentectomy vs lobectomy (entire lobe) vs bilobectomy (two lobes) vs pneumonectomy (entire lung) - extent depends on disease location and severity
tips.notes: Surgeons aim for minimal resection while removing all diseased tissue. More extensive resections (lobectomy+) have longer recovery but may be necessary for cure.

tips.tip: Pre-surgery IV amikacin protocol controversial - recommended by some centers (NJH requires 6-10 weeks) but not all surgeons require it, especially if patient sensitive/resistant
tips.notes: Some patients refuse IV amikacin due to tinnitus/balance risks. Protocol varies by center - discuss alternatives if drug sensitivity test shows resistance.

tips.tip: Quality of life often improves dramatically post-surgery - reduced cough, fewer exacerbations, no more daily antibiotic side effects, and ability to discontinue toxic medications
tips.notes: Multiple patients report feeling better immediately after surgery, able to clear lungs more effectively, fewer infections, and relief from years of antibiotic burden.

tips.tip: Consider surgery earlier rather than later if cavities don't respond to 6 months antibiotics - Japanese studies show early resection prevents disease progression and improves cure rates
tips.notes: Waiting too long allows disease progression making surgery more extensive or impossible. Best outcomes when surgery done while patient still has good lung function and localized disease.

tips.tip: Long-term success stories: patients report 13-20 years MAC-free after surgery with diligent airway clearance, though some require maintenance antibiotics for bronchiectasis exacerbations
tips.notes: Two women MAC-free 20 years post-surgery. Another 13+ years post-surgery with no recurrence. Continued airway clearance essential to prevent reinfection.

tips.tip: Bronchial artery embolization is minimally invasive procedure for persistent hemoptysis (coughing blood) - doesn't treat MAC but stops bleeding to allow airway clearance to continue safely
tips.notes: For patients with frequent hemoptysis that prevents airway clearance. Not a cure but symptom management allowing continuation of essential nebulizer/vest therapy.

tips.tip: Pneumonectomy (total lung removal) is rare but sometimes necessary for extensive unilateral disease - patients can live normal lives with one lung but face permanent breathlessness
tips.notes: 70-year-old patient had successful pneumonectomy by Dr. Mitchell. Recovery difficult, weight/strength hard to regain, persistent shortness of breath, but cultures clear post-surgery.

tips.tip: Stay near hospital 2-4 weeks post-surgery for follow-up appointments - Hyatt Regency across from University of Colorado Hospital recommended by NJH surgical patients
tips.notes: Hyatt has overpass walkway to hospital. Patients book 1 month (cancellable) to ensure availability for any complications requiring extended stay.

tips.tip: Non-pulmonary NTM surgery considerations: extrapulmonary NTM (skin, soft tissue, joints, lymph nodes) requires surgical debridement plus antibiotics - different protocols than lung surgery
tips.notes: Patient with M. chelonae skin infection required multiple debridement surgeries. Another with MAC shoulder infection had 4 surgeries plus IV antibiotics.

tips.tip: Elective non-lung surgeries safe for MAC patients if proper sterile technique used - get pulmonologist clearance but no evidence MAC spreads to surgical sites with good infection control
tips.notes: Patients safely had spinal, gynecological, and orthopedic surgeries. Cutaneous NTM typically occurs from environmental exposure (contaminated water/equipment), not internal spread.

key_insights: Surgery is potentially curative for localized cavitary MAC disease but must be combined with 12+ months antibiotics post-operatively
Best outcomes occur when surgery performed early (after 6 months failed antibiotic therapy) while disease still localized and lung function preserved
Minimally invasive/robotic techniques dramatically reduce recovery time compared to traditional thoracotomy (2-3 weeks vs 2-3 months)
Specialist surgeon selection critical - Dr. Mitchell (NJH) and Dr. Caccitolo (Tyler) most experienced with NTM patients
Long-term success depends on continued diligent airway clearance post-surgery to prevent reinfection
Surgery removes bacterial reservoir (cavity) allowing immune system and antibiotics to work more effectively on remaining bacteria
Recurrence possible but less likely than with persistent cavities treated with antibiotics alone - many patients achieve 10-20 years disease-free
Recovery timeline: physical healing 6 weeks, stamina/energy recovery 6-12 months, permanent breathlessness if extensive resection

common_questions.question: Am I a candidate for surgery?
common_questions.answer: Best candidates have: localized cavitary disease (upper lobe typical), adequate lung function, culture-negative or convertible on antibiotics, cavity that doesn't shrink after 6+ months treatment, no major comorbidities, and ideally under 70 years old.

common_questions.question: What are the success rates for MAC surgery?
common_questions.answer: Cleveland Clinic reports 95% long-term clearance at 1 year, 87% at 3 years post-surgery when combined with continued antibiotics. Many patients report 10-20 years disease-free. Recurrence possible but less likely than antibiotic-only treatment with persistent cavities.

common_questions.question: How long is recovery from lung surgery?
common_questions.answer: Hospital stay 3-5 days. Minimally invasive: return to light work 2-3 weeks, full recovery 6 months. Traditional thoracotomy: return to work 2-3 months, full recovery 6-12 months. Energy/stamina takes longer to recover than physical healing.

common_questions.question: Will I need IV amikacin before surgery?
common_questions.answer: Protocol varies - NJH typically requires 6-10 weeks IV amikacin pre-op, but some surgeons don't require it especially if sensitivity testing shows resistance. Discuss alternatives if you have tinnitus/balance concerns.

common_questions.question: Can surgery cure my MAC?
common_questions.answer: Surgery removes the bacterial reservoir (cavity/destroyed tissue) but doesn't guarantee cure - residual bacteria remain in lungs. Must continue antibiotics 12 months post-op. Many achieve long-term remission (10-20+ years) with diligent airway clearance, but reinfection remains possible.

common_questions.question: Should I wait to see if antibiotics close my cavity or have surgery now?
common_questions.answer: Japanese studies recommend surgery if cavity doesn't respond after 6 months antibiotics. Waiting too long allows disease progression, making surgery more extensive/risky. Best outcomes when surgery done early while disease localized and lung function good.

common_questions.question: What are the major risks of lung surgery?
common_questions.answer: Post-op mortality 0-23%, morbidity 0-50% depending on procedure extent. Common complications: nerve pain (usually temporary), persistent numbness, fatigue, breathlessness if extensive resection, air leaks, infections. Specialist NTM surgeons have lower complication rates.

common_questions.question: Which surgeon should I choose for NTM lung surgery?
common_questions.answer: Dr. John Mitchell (University of Colorado/NJH) and Dr. James Caccitolo (Tyler, TX) most frequently recommended. Choose high-volume thoracic surgeon experienced specifically with bronchiectasis/NTM patients, not general thoracic surgeon.
